questions.question: What is the SI unit of electric current?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The SI Unit of electric current is the ampere.'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: What is the SI unit of electric charge?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The SI unit of charge (Q) is Coulomb (C).'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: What is the SI unit of potential difference?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The S.I unit of potential difference is Volt (V).'

questions.question: The unit Volt is named after which scientist?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'It is named after the Italian Physicist Alessandro Volta.'

questions.question: Which subatomic particle is negatively charged?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'electrons are negatively charged'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: Which subatomic particle is positively charged?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Protons are positively charged'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: Which subatomic particle has no charge?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'neutrons do not have any charge, that is, they are neutral.'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The centre of an atom is called the:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The centre of the atom is called the nucleus.'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The nucleus of an atom consists of:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'It consists of protons and neutrons.'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: Electrons revolve around the nucleus in paths called:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Electrons revolve around the nucleus in paths called orbits.'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The direction of conventional current is from:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'the direction of flow of electric current is taken to be from the positive terminal of the battery... to the negative terminal.'

questions.question: The direction of conventional current is _____ to the direction of flow of electrons.
questions.explanation: The text states: 'the direction of the conventional current is taken to be opposite to the direction of flow of electrons.'

questions.question: Who developed the dry cell in 1887?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'It was developed in 1887 by Yai Sakizo of Japan.'

questions.question: In a dry cell, which electrode is positive?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A carbon rod with a brass cap is placed at the centre. This acts as a positive electrode'

questions.question: In a dry cell, which electrode is negative?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A dry cell essentially consists of a zinc container, acting as the negative electrode.'

questions.question: The positive electrode is also called:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The positive electrode is called the anode'

questions.question: The negative electrode is also called:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'the negative electrode is called the cathode.'

questions.question: The electrolyte in a dry cell is a moist paste of:
options: B. Ammonium chloride and plaster of Paris
questions.correct_answer: B. Ammonium chloride and plaster of Paris
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The electrolyte is a moist paste of ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) and plaster of Paris.'

questions.question: Which type of cell cannot be recharged?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The dry cell commonly used in torches is an example of a primary cell. It cannot be recharged after use.'

questions.question: Which type of cell can be recharged?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Secondary cells are used in automobiles and generators. The chemical reaction on them can be reversed, hence they can be recharged.'

questions.question: Secondary cells are also called:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Secondary cells are also called storage cells or accumulators.'

questions.question: A battery is formed by connecting multiple cells in:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A number of primary cells connected in series forms a battery.'

questions.question: What converts mechanical energy into electrical energy?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'An electric generator or dynamo is a device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.'

questions.question: In hydroelectric power stations, what rotates the turbines?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'In hydroelectric power stations, turbines are rotated by flowing water.'

questions.question: A thermal power plant uses energy from:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A thermal power plant uses energy produced from fossil fuels such as coal, diesel or natural gas'

questions.question: A nuclear power plant uses what type of energy?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'An atomic or nuclear power plant uses nuclear energy to generate electric current.'

questions.question: What device converts solar energy into electrical energy?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The device used to convert solar energy into electrical energy is called the solar cell.'

questions.question: A solar panel is formed by:
options: A. A single large solar cell
B. A large number of solar cells connected together
questions.correct_answer: B. A large number of solar cells connected together
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A solar panel is formed by a large number of solar cells connected together.'

questions.question: Where are solar panels used according to the text?
options: C. In artificial satellites and space stations
questions.correct_answer: C. In artificial satellites and space stations
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Solar panels are used in artificial satellites and space stations.'

questions.question: An electric circuit is defined as:
options: B. A closed path in which electric current flows
questions.correct_answer: B. A closed path in which electric current flows
questions.explanation: The text states: 'An electric circuit is defined as a closed path in which electric current flows.'

questions.question: A circuit is closed when:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A circuit is said to be closed or complete when electric current flows through it. This condition is obtained when the switch is on.'

questions.question: In a series circuit, if one appliance stops working:
options: B. Other appliances also stop working
questions.correct_answer: B. Other appliances also stop working
questions.explanation: The text states: 'If any appliance gets damaged, the remaining appliances also stop working because the circuit gets broken due to the damaged appliance.'

questions.question: In a parallel circuit, if one appliance stops working:
options: C. Remaining appliances continue to work
questions.correct_answer: C. Remaining appliances continue to work
questions.explanation: The text states: 'If any appliance gets damaged, the remaining ones continue to work as all appliances work independently.'

questions.question: In household wiring, appliances are connected in:
options: C. Both series and parallel equally
questions.explanation: The text states: 'in household wiring system, all the appliances are connected in parallel with separate switches.'

questions.question: Substances which allow electric current to flow through them are called:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Substances which allow electric current to flow through them easily are called conductors.'

questions.question: Which of the following is an insulator?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Cotton, rubber, paper, glass, ceramics, plastic, wood and pure water are insulators.'

questions.question: Why is copper used in making electric wires?
options: C. It is a good conductor
questions.correct_answer: C. It is a good conductor
questions.explanation: The text states: 'That is why copper is used in making good quality electric wires and other electrical components.'

questions.question: Electric wires are covered with plastic because:
options: B. Plastic is an insulator and makes them safe
questions.correct_answer: B. Plastic is an insulator and makes them safe
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Electric wires are always covered with insulators, such as plastic, to make them safe.'

questions.question: The component that opposes the flow of current in a circuit is called:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A resistor which opposes the flow of current in the circuit.'

questions.question: What should you stand on while doing electrical work?
options: C. Rubber mat or wooden board
questions.correct_answer: C. Rubber mat or wooden board
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Stand on an insulator such as a rubber mat or a wooden board when doing electrical work.'

questions.question: What is electric current caused by?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The flow of charges takes place due to the movement of free electrons.'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: If 1 coulomb of charge flows through a conductor in 1 second, the current is:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'If one coulomb of charge (Q) flows through a conductor in one second, the current (I) flowing through the conductor is one ampere (1A).'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The mathematical formula for electric current is:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Mathematical relation between electric current (I) and electric charge (Q) is represented as: I = Q/t.'
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: 1 Volt equals:
questions.explanation: The text states: '1 Volt = 1 Joule/ 1 Coulomb. 1V = 1J/1C.'

questions.question: Potential difference can be defined as:
options: B. Amount of work done in moving a unit charge from one point to another
questions.correct_answer: B. Amount of work done in moving a unit charge from one point to another
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Potential difference between any two points can also be defined as the amount of work done in moving a unit charge from one point to another.'

questions.question: Which region has high potential?
options: B. Region with accumulation of electrons
questions.correct_answer: B. Region with accumulation of electrons
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A high potential region is produced by the accumulation of electrons due to larger force of repulsion.'

questions.question: Electric current flows only when there is:
options: C. Equal potential at both ends
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Thus, an electric current flows only when there is a potential difference.'

questions.question: In a torch cell, the positive terminal is marked as:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'If you observe a torch cell, you will find one end marked positive (+) and the other end marked negative (-).'

questions.question: The electrolyte in a dry cell is in the form of:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The electrolyte is a moist paste of ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) and plaster of Paris.'

questions.question: The carbon rod in a dry cell is surrounded by:
options: B. Manganese dioxide and carbon in a muslin bag
questions.correct_answer: B. Manganese dioxide and carbon in a muslin bag
questions.explanation: The text states: 'is surrounded by a mixture of manganese dioxide (MnO2) and carbon (C) in a muslin bag.'

questions.question: The brass cap in a dry cell acts as:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'the brass cap at the top acts as the positive terminal.'

questions.question: The metal case at the bottom of a dry cell acts as:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The metal case at the bottom acts as the negative terminal'

questions.question: What happens when chemicals in a dry cell are used up?
options: B. Cell has to be discarded
questions.correct_answer: B. Cell has to be discarded
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Once the chemicals are used up, the cell can no longer be used, and it has to be discarded.'

questions.question: Which of the following is an advantage of a dry cell?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Moreover, there is no fear of leakage in dry cells.'

questions.question: Dry cells are used in:
options: B. Television remotes, torches, calculators and toys
questions.correct_answer: B. Television remotes, torches, calculators and toys
questions.explanation: The text states: 'These cells are used in a number of household gadgets such as television remotes, torches, calculators and toys.'

questions.question: The chemical reaction inside a primary cell is:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The chemical reaction inside the primary cell is irreversible.'

questions.question: The chemical reaction inside a secondary cell is:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The chemical reaction inside the secondary cell is reversible.'

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a primary cell?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Examples of primary cells are simple voltaic cell, Daniel cell, Leclanche cell and dry cell.'

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a secondary cell?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Examples of secondary cells are lead accumulator, Edison accumulator and nickel-iron accumulator.'

questions.question: Primary cells are used to operate:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'It is used to operate small devices such as torches, toys, radios, bicycles and small tape recorders.'

questions.question: Secondary cells are used to operate:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'It is used to operate devices such as mobile phones, cameras, computers and emergency lights.'

questions.question: We obtain electricity to operate domestic appliances from the:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'We obtain electricity to operate domestic appliances from the mains.'

questions.question: Electricity for domestic purposes is generated at:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Electricity for domestic and industrial purposes is generated at electric power stations.'

questions.question: A dynamo is another name for:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'An electric generator or dynamo is a device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.'

questions.question: In a generator, which material is rotated in a magnetic field?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'In a generator, an electric conductor such as copper wire is rotated in a magnetic field to produce an electric current.'

questions.question: Which type of power plant uses coal, diesel or natural gas?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A thermal power plant uses energy produced from fossil fuels such as coal, diesel or natural gas to produce electricity.'

questions.question: Small generators used at homes during power cuts use fuels such as:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Small generators such as those used at homes for back-up during power cuts use fuels such as diesel or kerosene to run the turbine.'

questions.question: Solar cells are used to power:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Solar cells are used to power electronic calculators, watches, streetlights and lighthouses.'

questions.question: The more the speed of wind, the more will be:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The more the speed of the wind, the more will be its energy and thus more electricity is generated.'

questions.question: What rotates to generate electricity from wind?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The energy of the wind is used to rotate the blades of a windmill, which in turn, generates electricity.'

questions.question: An electric circuit provides a complete path for flow of:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'connected so as to provide a complete path for the flow of charges from one terminal to the other terminal of a cell'

questions.question: Which component acts as a source of electricity in a circuit?
options: B. Cell, battery or AC mains
questions.correct_answer: B. Cell, battery or AC mains
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A cell, a battery or AC mains which act as a source of electricity.'

questions.question: What is the function of a switch in a circuit?
options: C. Turn on or off the electric device
questions.correct_answer: C. Turn on or off the electric device
questions.explanation: The text states: 'An electric switch to turn on or off the electric device.'

questions.question: A plug key helps in keeping a circuit:
options: A. Open or closed for longer duration
questions.correct_answer: A. Open or closed for longer duration
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A plug key which helps in keeping a circuit open or closed for longer duration.'

questions.question: When is a circuit said to be open?
options: B. When no electric current flows through it
questions.correct_answer: B. When no electric current flows through it
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A circuit is said to be open when no electric current flows through it.'

questions.question: A circuit diagram uses _____ to show the path of current.
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A circuit diagram is a convenient way to show the path of electric current on paper by using conventional symbols.'

questions.question: The arrow in a circuit diagram shows:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The arrow marked in a circuit diagram shows the direction of conventional current.'

questions.question: In a series circuit, there is _____ of voltage.
questions.explanation: The text states: 'There is a sharing of voltage (potential difference).' in series circuit.

questions.question: In a parallel circuit, each appliance gets:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Each appliance gets the original voltage.' in parallel circuit.

questions.question: In a series circuit, all appliances work:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'All appliances work simultaneously.' in series circuit.

questions.question: In a parallel circuit, all appliances work:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'All appliances work independently.' in parallel circuit.

questions.question: The measure of opposition to current flow is called:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The measure of the opposition to current flow in an electrical circuit is known as resistance.'

questions.question: A resistor in a circuit limits or regulates:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A resistor in an electrical circuit limits or regulates the flow of electricity.'

questions.question: Which of the following is a conductor?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'All metals such as copper, silver, nickel, aluminium, iron and steel are conductors.'

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a conductor?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'glass, ceramics, plastic, wood and pure water are insulators.'

questions.question: Is the human body a conductor?
options: B. Yes, but not as good as metals
questions.correct_answer: B. Yes, but not as good as metals
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The human body also allows current to pass through it, but it is not as good a conductor as metals.'

questions.question: Impure water is a:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Impure water is also a conductor.'

questions.question: Pure water is a:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'pure water are insulators.'

questions.question: Air is a:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Air is an insulator.'

questions.question: If any part of a circuit is broken, there is no flow of current because:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Air is an insulator. Therefore, if any part of the circuit is broken, there is no flow of electric current.'

questions.question: What percentage of outside power lines are bare and uninsulated?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'In fact, 90% of outside power lines are bare wires and uninsulated.'

questions.question: Why should we not touch electrical appliances with wet hands?
options: B. Tap water and body are conductors
questions.correct_answer: B. Tap water and body are conductors
questions.explanation: The text states: 'tap water and your body, being good conductors of electricity, will cause the current to flow through the body.'

questions.question: What should be done in case of short circuit and fire?
options: B. Put off the main switch immediately
questions.correct_answer: B. Put off the main switch immediately
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Put off the main switch immediately in case of short circuit and fire.'

questions.question: Which mark indicates that an electrical appliance is safe to use?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The ISI mark indicates that an electrical appliance is safe to use.'

questions.question: A fuse is a safety device that:
options: B. Contains a wire that melts when current exceeds limit
questions.correct_answer: B. Contains a wire that melts when current exceeds limit
questions.explanation: The text states: 'A fuse is a safety device containing a wire that melts and breaks the electric circuit when the current exceeds permissible value.'

questions.question: What is a drawback of a fuse?
options: B. It needs to be replaced every time there is overflow of current
questions.correct_answer: B. It needs to be replaced every time there is overflow of current
questions.explanation: The text states: 'One major drawback of a fuse is that it needs to be replaced every time there is an overflow of current.'

questions.question: MCB stands for:
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Miniature Circuit Breakers (MCBs) are commonly used in homes and commercial settings.'

questions.question: Which is more sensitive to current - fuse or MCB?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'An MCB is more sensitive to current than a fuse'

questions.question: Who invented the Leclanche cell?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Georges Leclanche (1839-1882) was a French scientist, chiefly remembered for his invention of the Leclanche cell.'

questions.question: In what year was the Leclanche cell invented?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'In 1866, he invented the Leclanche cell'
